repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
When nvim -es is specified, the user enters ex mode and we don't enable the terminal UI.  In the modern day, the user is typically using this for scripting, but this also serves an important functionality as an editor of last resort when the user finds themselves without a terminal. ex mode is fully functional even on dumb terminals or when the terminfo database is broken, and this can allow a user to recover their system.

However, there's no reason that a user shouldn't be able to use this more interactively even if they do have a TTY.  This is not a common thing to want to do, but it should be possible.  There are some users who prefer an editor that does not take up the entire terminal, but may enjoy the flexibility and functionality of Neovim, so ex mode may be a good fit for them.

At the moment, though, Neovim breaks this use case by explicitly checking for a missing terminal before enabling input.  As a result, since we've enabled silent mode, we have no terminal UI to read data from and we don't read from standard input, so we just silently read nothing, and exit.

This is definitely not what the user wanted or what they asked for, and it's bizarre to make this work only when the user is missing a TTY, so let's just skip the TTY check altogether here so it works the same regardless.

Skip the test assertions on Windows because there the terminal outputs extra escape sequences we don't want and don't control. However, on other operating systems, this test needs to verify that the output is exactly as specified and doesn't contain any escape sequences, since users specifically will not want colors or other text with -es.

comment_data.body: There may be a data race here. If the output for `%print` is produced before `q!` is received, `cv` may appear before `q!`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -593,6 +593,36 @@ describe('startup', function()
     eq('  encoding=utf-8\n', fn.system({ nvim_prog, '-n', '-es' }, { 'set encoding', '' }))
   end)
 
+  it('can use -es with a TTY', function()
+    exec([[
+      func Normalize(data) abort
+        " Remove ^M
+        return map(a:data, 'substitute(v:val, "\r", "", "g")')
+      endfunc
+      func OnOutput(id, data, event) dict
+        let g:stdout = Normalize(a:data)
+      endfunc
+      let id = jobstart([v:progpath, '-es'], {
+      \ 'pty': v:true,
+      \ 'stdout_buffered': v:true,
+      \ 'on_stdout': function('OnOutput'),
+      \ })
+      call chansend(id, "put =mode(1)\r")
+      call chansend(id, "%print\r")
+      call chansend(id, "q!\r")

comment_data.body: I can send the data all at once, which should make it nearly impossible for that to happen since the PTY will echo it all at once as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -593,6 +593,36 @@ describe('startup', function()
     eq('  encoding=utf-8\n', fn.system({ nvim_prog, '-n', '-es' }, { 'set encoding', '' }))

comment_data.body: I've pushed a change which does that and should also eliminate the possibility of a data race at all.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -593,6 +593,36 @@ describe('startup', function()
     eq('  encoding=utf-8\n', fn.system({ nvim_prog, '-n', '-es' }, { 'set encoding', '' }))
   end)
 
+  it('can use -es with a TTY', function()
+    exec([[
+      func Normalize(data) abort
+        " Remove ^M
+        return map(a:data, 'substitute(v:val, "\r", "", "g")')
+      endfunc
+      func OnOutput(id, data, event) dict
+        let g:stdout = Normalize(a:data)
+      endfunc
+      let id = jobstart([v:progpath, '-es'], {
+      \ 'pty': v:true,
+      \ 'stdout_buffered': v:true,
+      \ 'on_stdout': function('OnOutput'),
+      \ })
+      call chansend(id, "put =mode(1)\r")
+      call chansend(id, "%print\r")
+      call chansend(id, "q!\r")

comment_regular_data.body: I believe the two macOS test failures are flakes.  They passed on a previous run and seem to have failed on unrelated items.

I'd prefer to make `nvim --headless +'norm! gQ'` or something like that, work instead. That allows us to simplify `nvim -es` and make its behavior more useful for scripts (e.g. by *not* printing visual/UI elements, only script output; and by always print LF newlines instead of CRLF).

> there's no reason that a user shouldn't be able to use this more interactively even if they do have a TTY

The reason is that it may allow us to simplify the code and allow use to reason about things more easily. I think we haven't really spent time on that yet, so this is currently just speculation.

> I'd prefer to make `nvim --headless +'norm! gQ'` or something like that, work instead. That allows us to simplify `nvim -es` and make its behavior more useful for scripts (e.g. by _not_ printing visual/UI elements, only script output; and by always print LF newlines instead of CRLF).

`vim -es` works in Vim without a problem and I use it from time to time.  I'd also like to use it in Neovim with `nvim -es`, since I don't want to have to need to have both Neovim and Vim installed at the same time.  Note that `nvim -e` is not suitable here because that echos colours and takes over the entire screen and that may or may not be possible or desirable.

I also just saw someone asking to use `ed` on StackOverflow because they wanted an editor that wasn't full-screen and I could have answered that question while also explaining that there are versions of `ex` that might be more functional.  That's what led me to make another attempt at this (the previous one was #16990) and finally figure out how to write a test (I think a suitable test I could use as a basis was introduced in that time).

I'll note that `nvim --headless +"norm! gQ"` doesn't actually work now, so I can't tell you what might or might not work about that approach.  It's certainly less discoverable because `vi -e` is `ex` and `ex -s` has the behaviour many people are expecting across implementations (including the BSD `nvi`).  So in my view, it would be a disservice to people to use a different approach for Neovim when we know that it is commonly installed as `vi` on a variety of systems.
I'm sorry, _where_ is `nvim` installed as `vi`? I have never heard of such a thing, and this (vi compatibility) is certainly not a primary project goal.

> I'm sorry, _where_ is `nvim` installed as `vi`? I have never heard of such a thing, and this (vi compatibility) is certainly not a primary project goal.

Debian and Ubuntu have it in the alternatives system for `vi`:

```console
$ sudo update-alternatives --config vi
There are 4 choices for the alternative vi (providing /usr/bin/vi).

  Selection    Path               Priority   Status
------------------------------------------------------------
* 0            /usr/bin/vim.gtk3   50        auto mode
  1            /bin/elvis-tiny     10        manual mode
  2            /usr/bin/nvi        20        manual mode
  3            /usr/bin/nvim       30        manual mode
  4            /usr/bin/vim.gtk3   50        manual mode
```

In the case above, if `vim.gtk3` were not installed, then the default would be `nvim`, since it would be the highest priority, and of course the system administrator can set any of those particular choices (including `nvim`) to `vi` at any time (in this case, by choosing option number 3).

I think it may be worth noting that (as I understand it) being a member of the `vi` alternative on Debian doesn't mean that the implementation is supposed to provide bug-for-bug compatibility with the original `vi` or the POSIX definition of `vi`.  None of those implementations provide that (since none of them provide open mode) and Debian definitely ships Vim in `nocp` mode by default with some non-default features enabled.

The question is rather, "Would a reasonable person think this is a reasonable implementation of `vi` and want to use it as such?"  I think that's a yes for Neovim: I use it because it has all of the vi goodness I want (excepting the functionality in this PR, which I'm hoping you'll accept).  Most of the people I know who use Neovim like the features and functionality along with the fact that it strongly resembles vi, even though it's not 100% compatible (which I don't think they want).

Anyway, I think this is getting a bit off topic, so let me try to steer us back to the PR in question.

No, sorry, this is very much on-topic because it determines whether your change is wanted. According to `man nvim`:

>      -es         Silent (non-interactive) Ex mode, reading stdin as Ex commands.  Useful for scripting
>                  because it does NOT start a UI, unlike -e.  :help silent-mode

So this is behaving exactly as intended. You say that `nvim -e` is not usable because of "colors", so _that_ would be a "fix" (if it's not due to a misconfigured terminfo).

> `vim -es` works in Vim without a problem and I use it from time to time.

Many things in vim "work" by accident, but not consistently or on all platforms.

I wrote about this extensively here: https://sink.io/jmk/vim-social-life/

Also as mentioned in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/16990 : 

> * `-es` seems weird for interactive stuff, because the `-s` means "silent" (aka "script" in Nvim).

This matters to me because it's a one-way door. If we decide now to support `nvim -es` for interactive use, we can't undo that later. There needs to be a strong motivation, not a rarely-used vi behavior.

> it would be a disservice to people to use a different approach for Neovim when we know that it is commonly installed as `vi` on a variety of systems.

`gQ` enters Ex mode. Why isn't that an acceptable alternative?

If running `TERM=dumb nvim` is broken, we need to fix that.

> as an editor of last resort when the user finds themselves without a terminal

`TERM=dumb nvim` is currently broken. That should be fixed, instead of changing the behavior of `nvim -es`.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(main): allow nvim -es to be used interactively with a TTY
